episode_summary: This episode of "No Such Thing As A Fish" covers a range of quirky and intriguing topics, including Franz Kafka's humorous attempt to convince his family of a tuberculosis cure, the adhesive properties of gecko feet even after death, the historical use of Thomas Beckett's blood in early homeopathy, and a failed crowdfunding attempt for a UFO museum in London.

facts.fact: Franz Kafka once convinced his entire family that Einstein's theory of relativity was going to cure his tuberculosis.
Dead geckos still stick to walls.
The active ingredient in the first ever homeopathy treatment was the blood of Thomas Beckett.
In 2013, a group of people attempted to crowdfund London's first ever UFO museum.
